options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: None
N/A
None
Virtual office hours
n/a
recorded lectures, virtual office hours
We largely had online lectures that were recorded, and two projects, one of which was a presentation given to the class.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned the fundamentals of neural networks, specifically with a focus on computer vision. We covered fully-connected neural networks, convolutional neural networks, back-propagation, batch normalization, and spiking neural networks. We also discussed hardware such as the CPU GPU distinction, neural network accelerators, cross-bar architectures, and liquid state machines. The hardware section of the course is based entirely on recent (past 5 years) research in the field of machine learning.
General overview of NN and interesting new state of the art methods.
I learned about various approaches to neural networks.
I learned about how neural networks work and more importantly, what people are doing at the forefront of the field.
Wonderful class to build a foundational understanding of different neural network architectures.
Broad overview of Neural Networks from a software and a hardware perspective.
Very high level understanding of neural networks and their architecture. No real in depth coverage of techniques or mathematical background on neural networks.
I learned about neural networks and models
high level knowledge of most deep learning fields
neural networks, software and hardware
We talked in depth about neural networks, both from a design and hardware angle, then discussed contemporary movements and papers on the subject.

I learned about the fundamentals of neural networks, especially convolutional neural networks, at a detailed technical level. I gained a surface-level understanding of hardware approaches and more recent work in this field. The course gave some practice in research skills, but there was little guidance in this area.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned the fundamentals of neural networks, specifically with a focus on computer vision. We covered fully-connected neural networks, convolutional neural networks, back-propagation, batch normalization, and spiking neural networks. We also discussed hardware such as the CPU GPU distinction, neural network accelerators, cross-bar architectures, and liquid state machines. The hardware section of the course is based entirely on recent (past 5 years) research in the field of machine learning.
I liked the project at the end.  I think the student presentation logistics could have been improved.

Strengths:
- We covered a lot of different topics in class, which were very interesting.

Weaknesses:
- I think the group projects could have been arranged better since some people were not able to form groups.
- Assignments were not graded in a timely manner.
The virtual format was very difficult.

This class was full of interesting material overall, and the psets helped me understand the concepts we were learning. The problem is that the psets left me largely unprepared for the final project, since the psets had helped guide us through the NNs we were trying to build, and the final project was left completely open-ended and had to be created from scratch.

The course was very approachable and gave students lots of space to explore their own personal interests in the assignments. The coding work, however, was really easy to I'm not sure we really got much from them. That was a pro and con because it meant the assignments were fast and straightforward but then again we probably wont take much away from the course.

Strengths: Caring Ta.
Weaknesses: lectures are slow and no time for questions. Never got a strong understanding of architectures.
I would recommend that the lectures and homework assignments better align.

I learned about neural network models but it would have been helpful to have more feedback during the process of the final project. I wished there was more explanation in the code we were writing for the problem sets.

It would be nice if more effort was put into creating assignments that would prepare us for the final project, instead of having to fill in single lines of code on assignments, and then be expected to write fully working pytorch code and come up with new deep learning stuff on the final project.

I think it would have been better to have the student presentations spread out instead of having them all on the same day, so instead of having 4 in one class it could have been nice to have one or two at the start of class
The course was interesting, but slightly repetitive. The assignments were pretty straightforward and all of the lectures followed a similar rhythm.

The first half of the course was taught well, with homework that reinforced the key lessons, though the step-by-step frameworks given for these assignments sometimes seemed unnecessarily detailed and took away from the useful challenges. The second half, focused on hardware and recent research, seemed much less effective because most students lacked the background necessary to understand the technical details of this work. A reduction in scope in exchange for greater depth would have been an improvement. The final project, while interesting, felt too broad and too heavily emphasized for a course with otherwise introductory material on neural networks. A more limited project, together with exams or more substantial programming assignments, would have been better. I'd also have appreciated written feedback on major assignments, instead of just grades.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think that the presentations during lecture times was logistically hard due to timezone differences, but the course was good other than that.  I especially thought that the coding assignments were good for online learning.

I liked having the lectures recorded and available online. We all had to present at some point, which initially would seem like a challenge given the virtual nature of the course, but ended up being perfectly doable.
This was a straightforward recorded lecture. I dont think there were many COVID specific tools we used.

Succeeded: easy assignments for the most part done online 
Improve: professor office hours and communication
The lectures were all recorded and it was helpful
n/a
The class made all information easily available online.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would highly recommend this course to any student in STEM. You will likely learn neural network techniques which are directly applicable to your research and you can use the final project to supplement your research.
I would recommend this course because Professor Panda taught it very well.
Yes. You'll learn not only about how neural networks work, but also about the most recent developments in the field.

Great class if you are interested in learning about different neural network architectures. Professor Panda is WONDERFUL. She is an incredible teacher and cares a lot about her students. Workload is very manageable.

Yup! This class can give you as much as you want from it. Lots of space to explore your own interests and be really engaged. Also lots of opportunity to be less engaged and take the class in a lowkey way.

No. The class is pretty easy aside from the last pset. But if you struggle, be ready for the professor to insult the class. The last assignment is rather challenging as you are provided broken code (and there is no real coding prerequisite) and the professor doesn't really want to help.
The final project also asks you to go do novel research as an undergrad. And only gives you three weeks. Big crunch.
Yes!
The course was interesting but I wished I learned more from the psets.
No
I would recommend this class to anyone who is definitely interested in going on a deep dive into neural networks.

I'd recommend this course in part. The first half of the course, focused on a hands-on introduction to neural networks with applications, was well taught. The second part of the course turned to recent research with a focus on hardware, and since most students had little background for this section, I felt that it didn't produce a useful level of understanding. The final project was interesting, but felt over-emphasized in a course that is essentially introductory for its subject matter.
